title: Git vs.¬†OneDrive: The Data Scientist‚Äôs Guide
text:
Read Time: ~8 Minutes
As Data Scientists using Mac, Windows, or Linux, we live in two worlds. We deal with massive datasets (perfect for Cloud Storage) and version-dependent code (perfect for Git).
Deciding where to store a project can be confusing. Make the wrong choice, and you end up with corrupted repositories or lost versions. This guide breaks down exactly where your files belong.

title: Git vs.¬†OneDrive: The Data Scientist‚Äôs Guide
section: 1. The Decision Matrix: What Goes Where?
text:
1. The Decision Matrix: What Goes Where?
The fundamental difference is simple: OneDrive syncs the ‚ÄúNow‚Äù (making folders identical across devices), while GitHub tracks the ‚ÄúHistory‚Äù (how a file evolved line-by-line).






Tipüß™ The ‚ÄúNotepad Test‚Äù (Rule of Thumb)



Open your file in a basic text editor (Notepad/TextEdit).

Can you read it? (Python script, Markdown, CSV) ‚Üí Use GitHub.
Does it look like alien gibberish? (PDF, Excel, .pkl, .exe) ‚Üí Use OneDrive.











Feature
OneDrive / Dropbox
GitHub / GitLab




Best For
Final Results, Documents, Images
Source Code, Configs, Text


File Types
Binary (.docx, .pdf, .jpg, .zip)
Plain Text (.py, .R, .md, .tex)


Data Size
Great for Large Data (>100MB)
Poor for large files (Keep repo < 1GB)


Conflict Handling
Creates ‚ÄúConflicted Copy‚Äù files
Manual line-by-line merge

title: Git vs.¬†OneDrive: The Data Scientist‚Äôs Guide
text:
2. The ‚ÄúMirrored‚Äù Workflow (Recommended)
For research and data science, you shouldn‚Äôt choose one or the other. You need both, but they must remain separate.





flowchart LR

    ~/Projects/analysis
    (Scripts, Reports, Configs)"] 
    
    Cloud["‚òÅÔ∏è Cloud Storage
    ~/OneDrive/Data
    (Raw CSVs, Large Zips, Final PDFs)"]

    Git <-->|"Linked via Code"| Cloud

    style Git stroke:#2563eb,stroke-width:2px,fill:#fff,color:#333
    style Cloud stroke:#f59e0b,stroke-width:2px,fill:#fff,color:#333







How to link them safely (Mac/Win/Linux safe)
Use code that detects your OS automatically so you don‚Äôt have to change paths when switching from Mac to Windows.
R Example:
# path.expand("~") finds C:/Users/Name (Win) or /Users/Name (Mac)
data_path <- file.path(path.expand("~"), "OneDrive", "Research", "data.csv")
df <- read.csv(data_path)
Python Example:
from pathlib import Path
import pandas as pd

# Path.home() is the universal way to find the user folder
data_path = Path.home() / "OneDrive" / "Research" / "data.csv"
df = pd.read_csv(data_path)

title: Git vs.¬†OneDrive: The Data Scientist‚Äôs Guide
section: 3. The Danger Zone: Git INSIDE OneDrive
text:
3. The Danger Zone: Git INSIDE OneDrive






Important‚ö†Ô∏è CRITICAL WARNING



Never initialize a Git repository inside a synced OneDrive/Dropbox/iCloud folder.


Why? Sync clients (OneDrive) and Version Control (Git) fight over the hidden .git folder. This leads to:

Repo Corruption: OneDrive may ‚Äúsync‚Äù a file lock that Git needs.
Conflicted Copies: You will end up with files named script.py (Computer Name Conflicted Copy).

title: Git vs.¬†OneDrive: The Data Scientist‚Äôs Guide
section: 4. How to Fix It (Moving Out of OneDrive)
text:
4. How to Fix It (Moving Out of OneDrive)
If your project is currently stuck in OneDrive, follow these steps. Do NOT move it to ‚ÄúDocuments‚Äù (as Documents often auto-syncs to Cloud too).

Step 0: Create a Safe ‚ÄúProjects‚Äù Folder

üçé macOS: Create /Users/name/Projects (Do not put in Documents!)
ü™ü Windows: Create C:\Users\name\Projects (Do not put in Documents!)
üêß Linux: Create /home/name/Projects (Safe anywhere in ~)



Step 1: On Your Primary Computer

Move the Folder: Drag your project folder OUT of OneDrive and into your new Projects folder.
Verify: Open your terminal (Git Bash on Windows).
cd ~/Projects/my-project
git status
Cleanup: Check OneDrive. If a copy remains there, delete it to stop the sync confusion.



Step 2: On Your Secondary Computer
Do not try to ‚Äúfix‚Äù the existing folder on your second computer. It‚Äôs faster to start fresh.

Let OneDrive Sync: Wait for OneDrive to update. It should automatically remove the old folder.
Clone Fresh: Download a clean connection to GitHub in your safe local folder.
cd ~/Projects
git clone https://github.com/yourname/my-project.git

title: Git vs.¬†OneDrive: The Data Scientist‚Äôs Guide
text:
Summary

Code lives in ~/Projects (Git).
Data lives in ~/OneDrive (Cloud).
Never put Git inside OneDrive or Documents (if synced).

title: Anscombe‚Äôs quartet
text:
So, I am learning how to use ggplot. Here is one my first attempts and at the same time I discover that you need to use the gridExtra package to layout multiople ggplots. I am using one of my favourite datasets: the Anscombe quartet

library(ggplot2)
library(grid)
library(gridExtra)

data(anscombe)

The quartet comprises four datasets that have nearly identical simple descriptive statistics, yet appear very different when graphed.

p1<-ggplot(anscombe,aes(x1,y1))+geom_point()+geom_smooth(method="lm",se=FALSE,color="red")+xlim(3,16)
p2<-ggplot(anscombe,aes(x2,y2))+geom_point()+geom_smooth(method="lm",se=FALSE,color="red")+xlim(3,16)
p3<-ggplot(anscombe,aes(x3,y3))+geom_point()+geom_smooth(method="lm",se=FALSE,color="red")+xlim(3,16)
p4<-ggplot(anscombe,aes(x4,y4))+geom_point()+geom_smooth(method="lm",se=FALSE,color="red")+xlim(7,20)

grid.arrange(p1,p2,p3,p4,ncol=2)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
